The provisions of this section apply to situations where a pilot needs to exercise the authority of a pilot-in-command in which the pilot shall, whether manipulating the controls or not, be responsible for the operation of the aircraft in accordance with the rules of the air, except that the pilot-in-command may depart from these rules in circumstances that render such departure absolutely necessary in the interests of safety.
[Page: 373]

##### 12.2.1.3.1 {#id716-12.2.1.3.1}
12.2.1.3.1 If the aircraft is required to deviate from track to avoid adverse meteorological conditions and prior clearance cannot be obtained, an ATC clearance shall be obtained at the earliest possible time. Until an ATC clearance is received the pilot shall take the following actions: a) if possible, deviate away from an organized track or route system; Jan 2022                   12-14                     Issue 01
[Page: 373]

| Route centre Line track | Deviations 10NM | Level change |
| ----------------------- | --------------- | ------------ |
| East 000-179 magnetic | Left Right | Descend 300 ft Climb 300 ft |
| West 180-359 magnetic | Left Right | Climb 300 ft Descend 300 ft |
[Page: 374]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________ b) establish communications with and alert nearby aircraft by broadcasting, at suitable intervals: aircraft identification, flight level, position (including ATS route designator or the track) and intentions, on the frequency in use and on 121.5 MHz (or, as aback-up, on the inter-pilot air-to- air frequency 123.45 MHz); c) watch for conflicting traffic both visually and by reference to ACAS; Note. If, as a result of actions taken under the provisions of 12.2.1.3.1 b) and c) above, the pilot determines that there is another aircraft at or near the same flight level with which a conflict may occur, then the pilot is expected to adjust the path of the aircraft, as necessary, to avoid conflict. d) turn on all aircraft exterior lights (commensurate with appropriate operating limitations); e) for deviations of less than 10 NM remain at a level assigned by ATC; f) for deviations greater than 10 NM, when the aircraft is approximately 10 NM from track, initiate a level change in accordance with table shown below; Table 12-1 Actions by aircraft, if a revised ATC clearance cannot be obtained Route centre        Deviations Level change Line track          10NM East                Left            Descend 300 ft 000-179 magnetic       Right            Climb 300 ft West                Left             Climb 300 ft 180-359 magnetic       Right           Descend 300 ft g) when returning to track, be at its assigned flight level when the aircraft is within approximately 10 NM of the centre line; and h) if contact was not established prior to deviating, continue to attempt to contact ATC to obtain a clearance. If contact was established, continue to keep ATC advised of intentions and obtain essential traffic information.
[Page: 374]

12.2.2 ATS CONTINGENCIES Note. The various circumstances surrounding each contingency situation preclude the establishment of exact detailed procedures to be followed. Detailed Local instructions concerning the communication, navigation, surveillance and evacuation shall be contained in the relevant LATCIs and Tehran ACC operation manual (OM).
[Page: 374]

12.2.2.1 COMPLETE GROUND RADIO FAILURE
[Page: 374]

##### 12.2.2.1.1 {#id716-12.2.2.1.1}
12.2.2.1.1 In the event of complete failure of the ground radio equipment used for air traffic control service, the air traffic controller should: (i) attempt to establish radio communications on the emergency frequency 121.500 MHz; (ii) without delay inform all adjacent control positions or air traffic control units, as applicable, of the failure; (iii) apprise such positions or units of the current traffic situation; (iv) request their assistance, in respect of aircraft which may establish communications with those positions or units, in establishing and maintaining separation between such aircraft; and Jan 2022                   12-15                     Issue 01
[Page: 374]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________ (v) instruct adjacent control positions or air traffic control units to hold or re-route all controlled flights outside the area of responsibility of the position or air traffic control unit that has experienced the failure until such time that the provision of normal services can be resumed, unless able to continue to provide air traffic services by means of other available communication channels.
[Page: 375]

12.2.2.2 GENERAL PROCEDURES FOR NAVAID MALFUNCTIONS
[Page: 375]

12.2.2.2.1 When an aircraft reports a ground−based NAVAID malfunction, take the following actions: a) request a report from a second aircraft. b) if the second aircraft reports normal operations, continue use and report to the first aircraft and the ATS supervisor to inform the airworthiness watch office. c) if the second aircraft confirms the malfunction or in the absence of a second aircraft, report to the ATS supervisor to inform the maintenance unit.
[Page: 375]

12.2.2.2.2 When an aircraft reports a GNSS anomaly, request the following information and/or take the following actions: a) record the following minimum information: 1. aircraft type and call sign. 2. location or position, and level at the time where GNSS abnormally was observed. 3. date/time of occurrence. b) request a report from a second aircraft and if it confirms the abnormally record on the incident form. c) inform other aircraft and the relevant ATS units of the abnormally as reported. Phraseology: ATTENTION ALL AIRCRAFT, GNSS ANOMALY REPORTED IN THE VICINITY/AREA (position). Example: ATTENTION ALL AIRCRAFT, GNSS ANOMALY REPORTED IN THE AREA 30 NM EAST OF ISN DVOR.
[Page: 375]

12.2.2.3 EMERGENCY SEPARATION
[Page: 375]

12.2.2.3.1 If, during a contingency situation, it is not possible to ensure that the applicable horizontal separation can be maintained, emergency separation of half the applicable vertical separation minimum may be used, i.e. 500 ft between aircraft in airspace where a vertical separation minimum of 1000 ft is applied, and 1000 ft between aircraft in airspace where a 2000 ft vertical separation minimum is applied.
[Page: 375]

##### 12.2.2.3.2 {#id716-12.2.2.3.2}
12.2.2.3.2 When emergency separation is applied the flight crews concerned shall be advised that emergency separation is being applied and informed of the actual minimum used. Additionally, all flight crews concerned shall be provided with essential traffic information. Jan 2022                   12-16                     Issue 01
[Page: 375]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 376]

12.2.2.4 BLOCKED FREQUENCY
[Page: 376]

12.2.2.4.1 Direct communications between pilots and ATSUs can be adversely affected by simultaneous transmissions which, effectively, block all or part of intended messages. Moreover, whilst the situation may be apparent to the controller or another pilot, the individuals who inadvertently make such transmissions may be unaware. On hearing a simultaneous transmission, it can be helpful for the controller (or another pilot if it is the controller’s transmission which has been blocked) to draw attention to the situation using the word ‘blocked’.
[Page: 376]

12.2.2.4.2 In the event that the control frequency is inadvertently blocked by an aircraft transmitter, the following additional steps should be taken: a) attempt to identify the aircraft concerned; b) if the aircraft blocking the frequency is identified, attempts should be made to establish communication with that aircraft, e.g. on the emergency frequency 121.5 MHz, by SELCAL, through the aircraft operator’s company frequency if applicable, on any VHF frequency designated for air-to-air use by flight crews or any other communication means or, if the aircraft is on the ground, by direct contact; c) if communication is established with the aircraft concerned, the flight crew shall be instructed to take immediate action to stop inadvertent transmissions on the affected control frequency.
[Page: 376]

12.2.2.5 UNAUTHORIZED USE OF ATC FREQUENCY
[Page: 376]

12.2.2.5.1 Instances of false and deceptive transmissions on ATC frequencies which may impair the safety of aircraft can occasionally occur. In the event of such occurrences, the ATC unit concerned should: a) correct any false or deceptive instructions or clearances which have been transmitted; b) advise all aircraft on the affected frequency(ies) that false and deceptive instructions or clearances are being transmitted; c) instruct all aircraft on the affected frequency(ies) to verify instructions and clearances before taking action to comply; d) if practical, instruct aircraft to change to another frequency; and e) if possible, advise all aircraft affected when the false and deceptive instructions or clearances are no longer being transmitted.
[Page: 376]

12.2.2.5.2 Flight crews shall challenge or verify with the ATC unit concerned any instruction or clearance issued to them which they suspect may be false or deceptive.
[Page: 376]

12.2.2.5.3 Collect and report pertinent information regarding the incident and notify the operational supervisor of the false, deceptive transmission.
[Page: 376]

12.2.3 PROCEDURES IN REGARD TO AIRCRAFT EQUIPPED WITH (ACAS)
[Page: 376]

#### 12.2.3.1 {#id716-12.2.3.1}
12.2.3.1 The procedures to be applied for the provision of air traffic services to aircraft equipped with ACAS shall be identical to those applicable to non-ACAS equipped aircraft. In particular, the prevention of collisions, the establishment of appropriate separation and the information which might be provided in relation to conflicting traffic and to possible avoiding action shall conform with the normal ATS procedures and shall exclude consideration of aircraft capabilities dependent on ACAS equipment. Jan 2022                   12-17                     Issue 01
[Page: 376]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 377]

12.2.3.2 When a pilot reports an ACAS resolution advisory (RA), the controller shall not attempt to modify the aircraft flight path until the pilot reports “CLEAR OF CONFLICT”.
[Page: 377]

12.2.3.3 Unless informed by the pilot, ATC does not know when ACAS issues RAs. It is possible for ATC to issue instructions that are unknowingly contrary to ACAS RA indications. Therefore, it is important that ATC be notified when an ATC instruction or clearance is not being followed because it conflicts with an RA.
[Page: 377]

12.2.3.4 Pilots should use appropriate procedures by which an aeroplane climbing or descending to an assigned altitude or flight level may do so at a rate less than 8 m/s (or 1 500 ft/min) throughout the last 300 m (or 1 000 ft) of climb or descent to the assigned altitude or flight level when the pilot is made aware of another aircraft at or approaching an adjacent altitude or flight level, unless otherwise instructed by ATC. These procedures are intended to avoid unnecessary ACAS II RAs in aircraft at or approaching adjacent altitudes or flight levels. For commercial operations, these procedures should be specified by the operator.
[Page: 377]

12.2.3.5 Once an aircraft departs from its ATC clearance or instruction in compliance with an RA, or a pilot reports an RA, the controller ceases to be responsible for providing separation between that aircraft and any other aircraft affected as a direct consequence of the manoeuvre induced by the RA. The controller shall resume responsibility for providing separation for all the affected aircraft when: a) the controller acknowledges a report from the flight crew that the aircraft has resumed the current clearance; or b) the controller acknowledges a report from the flight crew that the aircraft is resuming the current clearance and issues an alternative clearance which is acknowledged by the flight crew. Note. Pilots are required to report RAs which require a deviation from the current ATC clearance or instruction. This report informs the controller that a deviation from clearance or instruction is taking place in response to an ACAS RA.
[Page: 377]

12.2.3.6 PROCEDURE FOR REPORTING RA’S: ATS supervisor shall be informed of reports that made by aircraft on RA to be entered in the log book.
[Page: 377]

12.2.4 GROUND PROXIMITY WARNING SYSTEM A controller is not to dissuade a pilot from climbing his aircraft upon receipt of a ground proximity warning. The message should be acknowledged and if appropriate QNH setting should be passed for confirmation.
[Page: 377]

12.2.5 CHANGE OF RADIOTELEPHONY CALL SIGN FOR AIRCRAFT Note. See also Para 3.2.9.4
[Page: 377]

#### 12.2.5.1 {#id716-12.2.5.1}
12.2.5.1 An ATC unit may instruct an aircraft to change its type of RTF call sign (e.g. to registration mark), in the interests of safety, when similarities between two or more aircraft RTF call signs are such that confusion is likely to occur. Note. In case of existence of call sign similarity, if the controller decides not to change the type of either of the call signs, he may warn pilots concerned by using one of the following phrases: a) “[1st call sign] be advised [2nd call sign] also on frequency” or b) “[call sign] [call sign] [instruction]” Jan 2022                   12-18                     Issue 01
[Page: 377]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 378]

12.2.5.1.1 Any such change to the type of call sign shall be temporary and shall be applicable only within the airspace(s) where the confusion is likely to occur.
[Page: 378]

12.2.5.1.2 To avoid confusion, the ATC unit should, if appropriate, identify the aircraft which will be instructed to change its call sign by referring to its position and/or level.
[Page: 378]

12.2.5.2 When an ATC unit changes the type of call sign of an aircraft, that unit shall ensure that the aircraft reverts to the call sign indicated by the flight plan when the aircraft is transferred to another ATC unit, except when the call sign change has been coordinated between the two ATC units concerned. Phraseology: CHANGE YOUR CALL SIGN TO (new call sign) [UNTIL FURTHER ADVISED];
[Page: 378]

#### 12.2.5.3 {#id716-12.2.5.3}
12.2.5.3 The appropriate ATC unit shall advise the aircraft concerned when it is to revert to the call sign indicated by the flight-plan. Phraseology: REVERT TO FLIGHT PLAN CALL SIGN (call sign) [AT (significant point)]. _______________________________________________________________ Jan 2022                   12-19                     Issue 01
[Page: 378]

.    SPECIAL     FLIGHTS Section 1 GENERAL   PRINCIPLES
[Page: 380]

13.1.1 FLIGHT PLANNING PROCEDURE Remarks and status indicator expressing the reasons for special handling by ATS, type of in section and any other accomplishment by special flight must be inserted in “Item 18” of flight plan.
[Page: 380]

### 13.1.2 {#id716-13.1.2}
13.1.2 SPECIAL OPERATIONS CLEARANCES As far as practicable the aircraft should be cleared according to pilot request. March 2022                   13-1                     Issue 02
[Page: 380]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________ Section 2 TYPE  OF SPECIAL  FLIGHTS Note. See also Tehran ACC OM, Chapter 7.
[Page: 381]

13.2.1 FLIGHT CHECK
[Page: 381]

13.2.1.1 Flight check aircraft engaged in operational trial and evaluation shall be provided with maximum possible assistance according to flight plan. Unless otherwise agreed, direct communications and exchange of information regarding known traffic in the area and intentions shall be maintained. Note 1. Many Flight Checks require an uninterrupted flight for successful completion of the mission. Note 2. Flight Check operations which require special participation of ground personnel, specific communications, or radar operation capabilities are considered to require special handling. These flights are coordinated with appropriate ATS unit before departure.
[Page: 381]

13.2.1.2 Flight check aircraft should not be subject to ATC delays except to preclude emergency situations.
[Page: 381]

13.2.1.3 Radar accuracy flight check shall not be advised to change the previously assigned discrete code.
[Page: 381]

13.2.2 AIRCRAFT CARRYING DANGEROUS GOODS
[Page: 381]

13.2.2.1 Aircraft carrying dangerous goods shall indicate this nature by insertion of STS/HAZMAT in item 18 of their flight plans for the provision of special handling. Note. Certain types of flights carrying dangerous materials require strict adherence to regulations, permission and flight planning as approved by appropriate authority along carefully selected routes.
[Page: 381]

13.2.2.2 Procedures concerning the alerting of the rescue and firefighting services shall be contained in local instructions. Such instructions shall specify the type of information to be provided to the rescue and firefighting services, including type of aircraft and type of emergency and, when available, number of persons on board, and any dangerous goods carried on the aircraft.
[Page: 381]

#### 13.2.2.3 {#id716-13.2.2.3}
13.2.2.3 If it becomes necessary to issue a clearance to amend the previously assigned route/level, the following action shall be taken by controller: a) inform the pilot of: 1. the proposed change, and 2. the expected delay if it is necessary to maintain the present route/level. b) when an amending clearance is not suitable to the pilot-in-command, the flight crew shall advise if the traffic delay is acceptable or an alternate desired route/level. In such cases, all possible assistance should be offered. c) when an aircraft is provided an en-route descent, shall not be vectored from the planned route unless the pilot concurs. d) use special patterns and routings in areas where they have been developed for these flights. If special patterns and routings have not been developed, employ normal procedures. e) notify the accepting unit and any other unit concerned. Jan 2022                   13-2                     Issue 01
[Page: 381]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 382]

13.2.3 HEAD FLIGHTS
[Page: 382]

13.2.3.1 flights are considered as head flights when: •  the word “HEAD” has been already included in FPL status “ITEM 18” which is issued by IRH (Islamic republic hanger) or; •  specified call signs issued by IRH in official letter or; •  approved by CAA.IRI.
[Page: 382]

13.2.3.2 ATCO shall report supervisor to inform ADOC about Head flight ETA.
[Page: 382]

13.2.3.3 ADOC shall be informed about entering Head flights as soon as possible. Note. Receiving politics messages transmitted by foreign Head over flights shall be withheld until coordination with supervisor for the purpose of recording.
[Page: 382]

13.2.4 PHOTOGRAPHY FLIGHT Photography flight operation is permitted only after pre-coordination with military and civil authorities as appropriate.
[Page: 382]

13.2.5 AGRICULTURE FLIGHT Agriculture flight operation is permitted only after pre-coordination with authorities as appropriate.
[Page: 382]

13.2.6 RAMADAN TIMING (NEW MOON(CRESCENT) OBSERVATION) FLIGHT When so requested in advance, an authorization for new moon observation flights may be issued.
[Page: 382]

13.2.7 CLOUD SEEDING FLIGHT The route and timing of these flights are determined by movement of the cloud area and not by traffic flow. ATCO should advise aircraft to contact nearest ATC unit if he suspects that two-way communication on ACC frequency is lost.
[Page: 382]

13.2.8 RESPONSIBILITY IN REGARD TO MANNED AND UNMANNED FREE BALLOONS On receipt of notification and after launch of the intended flight of a medium or heavy unmanned free balloon, the ATCO shall inform all ATS unit concerned.
[Page: 382]

### 13.2.9 {#id716-13.2.9}
13.2.9 MILITARY FLIGHT ACTIVITY Note. The phrase “APPROPRIATE MILITARY UNITS” in this context is taken to mean any permanently established military units controlling activities that may affect flights of civil aircraft. It is recommended, however, that the same requirement be applied also to temporarily established or mobile military units conducting potentially hazardous activities. Jan 2022                   13-3                     Issue 01
[Page: 382]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________ Note 2. For more information about coordination between military authorities and air traffic services see also CAA.IRI ATM/ANS article 3b.
[Page: 383]

13.2.9.1 It is recognized that some military aeronautical operations necessitate non-compliance with certain air traffic procedures. In order to ensure the safety of flight operations the appropriate military authorities according to the civil-military coordination procedure shall coordinate with appropriate ATS unit prior to undertaking such manoeuvres.
[Page: 383]

13.2.9.2 By prior acknowledgment of approval receipt, the military aircraft is required to wait for an air traffic control clearance before to proceeding under conditions requiring compliance with air traffic procedures. The following actions shall be taken, if necessary: a) flight plan shall be submitted prior departure and should contain supplementary information deemed necessary by ATC unit concerned; b) request pilot’s estimate for crossing route/points, the range of blocked levels and cruising flight level for the entire route or part thereof and changes of levels if required; c) the vacant cruising flight level shall be assigned due to the factors influencing the nature of the flight and lack of communication; d) military flight may be exempted from the requirement to make position report at each reporting point. Note. More details are contained in the civil-military coordination procedure and the relevant LATCIs.
[Page: 383]

13.2.9.3 SCRAMBLE FLIGHTS.
[Page: 383]

13.2.9.3.1 Definition: Scramble is an armed fighter for air combat with the mission of air defense in order to prevent a hostile fighter attacking Iranian airspace boundaries or a flight on ADOC decision and efforts for identification, interception, fight and if necessary destruction of an enemy fighter. The command for Scramble flight is issued by ADOC regional operation centres and the flight is controlled by ADOC radars from the beginning to the end of mission as indicated by ADOC.
[Page: 383]

13.2.9.3.1.1 Initial information on a scramble flight including, its initial direction and level, will be provided for to ATS units by the command post (CP) of the relevant air base, through recordable means of communication.
[Page: 383]

13.2.9.3.1.2 Scramble flight has priority over all other flights. Note. In case, an arriving emergency aircraft on final approach segment is in critical situation, it may be granted priority, provided it is agreed upon by the scramble flight.
[Page: 383]

13.2.9.3.2 Procedure of Scramble flights
[Page: 383]

13.2.9.3.2.1 Scramble flight will contact ADOC radars immediately after departure.
[Page: 383]

13.2.9.3.2.2 ADOC regional radar after receipt of information from ATS units will direct the Scramble flight with regard to other flights, also in the defined region by ADOC, ATS units will try to have close coordination with ADOC.
[Page: 383]

###### 13.2.9.3.2.3 {#id716-13.2.9.3.2.3}
13.2.9.3.2.3 On return, the Scramble like other armed military flights will contact approach unit and will be given priority for landing. Jan 2022                   13-4                     Issue 01
[Page: 383]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.3.2.4 Close coordination between ATS units and ADOC and relevant airbase command post (CP) in expedition of performing the Scramble flight is necessary. For airspace security of the country and safety of flight operations these units shall have close coordination.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.3.2.5 In case of scramble flight for interception of civil aircraft ADOC shall inform Tehran ACC.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.4 COMBAT AIR PATROL (CAP):
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.4.1 Definition: A Fighter with combat equipment for air coverage and prevention of possible penetration of enemy fighters to the airspace boundaries of the region, and the flight is performed for interception, fight and if necessary destruction of the enemy fighter before fulfilling its goals.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.4.2 Procedure of CAP flights:
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.4.2.1 Initial information on CAP flight will be provided for ATS units by the relevant command centre of the airbase in the region by the fastest recordable mean.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.4.2.2 With the coordination of ATS units, CAP flight will contact ADOC radar after departure.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.4.2.3 While in contact with ADOC regional radars, CAP flights will operate in the defined level and region and any change of level or flight area will be coordinated with ATS units.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.4.2.4 On return, the mentioned flight will contact approach unit like other armed military flights and will be given priority for landing as far as practicable.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.5 SPECIAL MISSION FLIGHTS (SM).
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.5.1 Definition: Military flights for cross-border operations or recognition, photography, eavesdropping and electronic war, confidential and flying radars are also in this category.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.5.2 Procedure of SM flight:
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.5.2.1 SM flights for cross-border operations will be done without submission of flight plan and radio communication, other SM flights will submit a flight plan via command post (CP) to the related ATS unit.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.5.2.2 Coordination with ATS units for SM flights is done by the relevant command post (CP)in joint civil-military airports.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.5.2.3 SM flights will operate on ADOC radar FRQs and required coordination will be effected with the related ATS units.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.5.2.4 SM flights information will be passed to the relevant ATS units “5” minutes before crossing of airways or control areas by the pilot or ADOC radars.
[Page: 384]

13.2.9.6 RADAR CHECK FLIGHTS
[Page: 384]

##### 13.2.9.6.1 {#id716-13.2.9.6.1}
13.2.9.6.1 Definition: Military flights with mission of checking ADOC radars, FRQs, equipment and ground to air armaments. They shall be done according to the predetermined parameters such as time, level, direction, starting and end points based on the accepted form. Jan 2022                   13-5                     Issue 01
[Page: 384]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.6.2 Procedure for radar check flights:
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.6.2.1 The time sensitivity of radar check flights are same as SM flights.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.6.2.2 The flight information shall be provided via close coordination by ADOC to the relevant ATS unit.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.6.2.3 Up to “4” radar check flight operation is acceptable during 24 hours (0000-2359) except when pre coordination is made through ADOC with the relevant ATS unit.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.6.2.4 Only one radar check flight is acceptable to operate in each ATS unit/sector AoR.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.6.2.5 As far as practicable military radar check flights should reach to the assigned flight level within TMA/CTR or related restricted area to be transferred to ADOC radar by the relevant ATS unit.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.6.2.6 It is necessary to assign the requested flight level which is submitted in flight plan by the concerned ATS units.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.7 AIR REFUELING FLIGHTS:
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.7.1 Definition: A flight with air refueling mission of fighters or military cargo aircraft.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.7.2 Procedure of air refueling flights
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.7.2.1 Air refueling flights will operate in B, C, E and K area as defined in the relevant LATCI and Tehran ACC OM.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.7.2.2 If necessary for air refueling in other areas, an advance coordination with Tehran ACC is mandatory.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.7.2.3 Submission of flight plan is mandatory for air refueling flight operations.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.8 FUNCTIONAL CHECK FLIGHTS (FCF):
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.8.1 Definition: A flight for flight approval after maintenance on the aircraft which needs more supervision and control.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.8.2 Procedure for FCF:
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.8.2.1 Command post(CP) shall use “STS/ TEST” for functional check flight (FCF) in “ITEM 18: OTHER INFORMATION” of flight plan.
[Page: 385]

13.2.9.8.2.2 ATS unit shall clear the FCF flights for the requested flight level as submitted in flight plan.
[Page: 385]

###### 13.2.9.8.2.3 {#id716-13.2.9.8.2.3}
13.2.9.8.2.3 In joint airports coordination procedures between air base and ATS unit will be prepared and inserted in relevant LATCI. Jan 2022                   13-6                     Issue 01
[Page: 385]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.9 SEA SEARCH FLIGHT
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.9.1 ATCO is responsible for provision of ATS, only when such aircraft has established two-way communication.
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.9.2 CPL shall not be closed until the transfer of control to destination has been done.
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.9.3 Sea search flights are considered as VFR flight while performing search mission.
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.10 MILITARY AIR TRANSPORT (CROSS COUNTRY) FLIGHT Military air transport flight are required to get special permission from the appropriate military authority prior entering Tehran FIR.
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.11 FORMATION FLIGHTS
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.11.1 The formation flight operates as a single aircraft with regard to navigation and position reporting;
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.11.2 Separation between aircraft in the flight shall be the responsibility of the flight leader and the pilots-in-command of the other aircraft in the flight and shall include periods of transition when aircraft are manoeuvring to attain their own separation within the formation and during join-up and breakaway; Note. For more details, see the relevant LATCIs.
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.11.3 A distance not exceeding 0.5 NM laterally and longitudinally and 100 ft vertically from the flight leader will be maintained by each aircraft; and Note. Separation responsibility between aircraft within the formation during transition to individual control rests with the pilots concerned until approved separation has been attained.
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.11.4 Formation flight including join-up and breakaway is only authorized in VMC.
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.12 MILITARY AND CIVIL FORMATION FLIGHTS IN RVSM AIRSPACE
[Page: 386]

13.2.9.12.1 Utilize RVSM separation standards for a formation flight, which consists of all RVSM approved aircraft.
[Page: 386]

##### 13.2.9.12.2 {#id716-13.2.9.12.2}

.   ATC   PHRASEOLOGIES Section 1 GENERAL
[Page: 388]

14.1.1 Most phraseologies contained in this manual show the text of a complete message without call signs. They are not intended to be exhaustive, and when circumstances differ, pilots, ATS personnel and other ground personnel will be expected to use plain language, which should be as clear and concise as possible, to the level specified in the ICAO language proficiency requirements, in order to avoid possible confusion by those persons using a language other than one of their national languages.
[Page: 388]

14.1.2 The phraseologies are grouped according to types of air traffic service for convenience of reference in “CHAPTER 14”. However, some phraseologies are grouped according to the subject in the body of this manual.
[Page: 388]

14.1.3 Words in parentheses indicate that specific information, such as a level, a place or a time, etc., must be inserted to complete the phrase, or alternatively that optional phrases may be used. Words in square parentheses indicate optional additional words or information that may be necessary in specific instances.
[Page: 388]

14.1.4 This chapter contains typical phraseologies to be used in the provision of air traffic services, arranged in groups to relate to the particular phase of air traffic services with which they are generally employed. Note 1. More examples of the application of the phraseologies may be found in the Manual of Radiotelephony (Doc 9432). Note 2. See 3.2.11.2. APPENDIX       1 AERODROME
[Page: 428]

1.1 COMMON REFERENCE SYSTEMS
[Page: 428]

1.1.1 HORIZONTAL REFERENCE SYSTEM World Geodetic System — 1984 (WGS-84) shall be used as the horizontal (geodetic) reference system. Reported aeronautical geographical coordinates (indicating latitude and longitude) shall be expressed in terms of the WGS-84 geodetic reference datum. Note. Comprehensive guidance material concerning WGS-84 is contained in the World Geodetic System — 1984 (WGS-84) Manual (Doc 9674).
[Page: 428]

1.1.2 VERTICAL REFERENCE SYSTEM Mean sea level (MSL) datum, which gives the relationship of gravity-related height (elevation) to a surface known as the geoid, shall be used as the vertical reference system. Note 1. The geoid globally most closely approximates MSL. It is defined as the equipotential surface in the gravity field of the Earth which coincides with the undisturbed MSL extended continuously through the continents. Note 2. Gravity-related heights (elevations) are also referred to as orthometric heights while distances of points above the ellipsoid are referred to as ellipsoidal heights.
[Page: 428]

1.1.3 TEMPORAL REFERENCE SYSTEM The Gregorian calendar and Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) shall be used as the temporal reference system. Note. When a different temporal reference system is used, this shall be indicated in GEN 2.1.2 of the Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP).
[Page: 428]

1.2 REFERENCE CODE
[Page: 428]

1.2.1 An aerodrome reference code — code number and letter — which is selected for aerodrome planning purposes shall be determined in accordance with the characteristics of the aeroplane for which an aerodrome facility is intended.
[Page: 428]

1.2.2 The aerodrome reference code numbers and letters shall have the meanings assigned to them in table Appendix 1-1.
[Page: 428]

### 1.2.3 {#id716-1.2.3}
1.2.3 The code number for element 1 shall be determined from table appendix 1-1, column 1, selecting the code number corresponding to the highest value of the aeroplane reference field lengths of the aeroplanes for which the runway is intended. Jan 2022                   A 1                     Issue 01
[Page: 428]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 429]

1.2.4 The code letter for element 2 shall be determined from table 3-23, column 3, by selecting the code letter which corresponds to the greatest wingspan, or the greatest outer main gear wheel span, whichever gives the more demanding code letter of the aeroplanes for which the facility is intended. [Page: 429]

1.3 AERODROME DATA
[Page: 429]

1.3.1 AERODROME REFERENCE POINT
[Page: 429]

1.3.1.1 An aerodrome reference point shall be established for an aerodrome.
[Page: 429]

1.3.1.2 The aerodrome reference point shall be located near the initial or planned geometric centre of the aerodrome and shall normally remain where first established.
[Page: 429]

1.3.2 AERODROME AND RUNWAY ELEVATIONS
[Page: 429]

1.3.2.1 The aerodrome elevation and geoid undulation at the aerodrome elevation position shall be measured to the accuracy of one-half meter or foot and reported to the aeronautical information services authority.
[Page: 429]

1.3.2.2 For an aerodrome used by international civil aviation for non-precision approaches, the elevation and geoid undulation of each threshold, the elevation of the runway end and any significant high and low intermediate points along the runway shall be measured to the accuracy of one-half meter or foot and reported to the aeronautical information services authority.
[Page: 429]

#### 1.3.2.3 {#id716-1.3.2.3}
1.3.2.3 For precision approach runway, the elevation and geoid undulation of the threshold, the elevation of the runway end and the highest elevation of the touchdown zone shall be measured to the accuracy of one- quarter meter or foot and reported to the aeronautical information services authority. Jan 2022                   A 2                     Issue 01
[Page: 429]

1.3.4 AERODROME DIMENSIONS AND RELATED INFORMATION The geographical coordinates of each threshold shall be measured and reported to the aeronautical information services authority in degrees, minutes, seconds and hundredths of seconds.

[Page: 430]

1.3.5.2 The bearing strength of a pavement intended for aircraft of apron (ramp) mass greater than 5700 kg shall be made available using the aircraft classification number — pavement classification number (ACN- PCN) method by reporting all of the following information: a) the pavement classification number (PCN); b) pavement type for ACN-PCN determination; c) subgrade strength category; d) maximum allowable tire pressure category or maximum allowable tire pressure value; and e) evaluation method.

1.4 PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS
[Page: 431]

1.4.1 RUNWAYS
[Page: 431]

#### 1.4.1.1 {#id716-1.4.1.1}
1.4.1.1 Actual length of runways: The actual runway length to be provided for a primary runway should be adequate to meet the operational requirements of the aeroplanes for which the runway is intended and should be not less than the longest length determined by applying the corrections for local conditions to the operations and performance characteristics of the relevant aeroplanes. Jan 2022                   A 4                     Issue 01
[Page: 431]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________ Note. When performance data on aeroplanes for which the runway is intended are not known, guidance on the determination of the actual length of a primary runway by application of general correction factors is given in the Aerodrome Design Manual (Doc 9157), Part 1.
[Page: 432]

1.4.1.2 Width of runways: The width of a runway should be not less than the appropriate dimension specified in the following tabulation: Table Appendix 1-6 Width of runways Code letter Code A        B        C       D        E       F number 1*      18 m    18 m     23 m     __       __      __ 2*      23 m    23 m     30 m     __       __      __ 3       30 m    30 m     30 m    45 m      __      __ 4       __       __      45 m    45 m     45 m    60 m *The width of a precision approach runway should be not less than 30 m where the code number is 1 or 2.
[Page: 432]

1.4.1.3 Longitudinal slopes: The slope computed by dividing the difference between the maximum and minimum elevation along the runway centre line by the runway length should not exceed: a) 1 per cent where the code number is 3 or 4; and b) 2 per cent where the code number is 1 or 2.
[Page: 432]

1.4.1.4 Transverse slopes: To promote the most rapid drainage of water, the runway surface should, if practicable, be cambered except where a single cross fall from high to low in the direction of the wind most frequently associated with rain would ensure rapid drainage. The transverse slope should ideally be: a) 1.5 percent where the code letter is C, D, E or F; and b) 2 percent where the code letter is A or B; but in any event should not exceed 1.5 per cent or 2 per cent, as applicable, nor be less than 1 per cent except at runway or taxiway intersections where flatter slopes may be necessary.
[Page: 432]

1.4.1.5 Runway strips: A runway and any associated stop-ways shall be included in a strip.
[Page: 432]

##### 1.4.1.5.1 {#id716-1.4.1.5.1}
1.4.1.5.1 Length of runway strips A strip shall extend before the threshold and beyond the end of the runway or stop-way for a distance of at least 360 m. Jan 2022                   A 5                     Issue 01
[Page: 432]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 433]

1.4.1.5.2 Width of runway strips A strip including a precision approach runway shall, wherever practicable, extend laterally to a distance of at least: a) 150 m where the code number is 3 or 4; and b) 75 m where the code number is 1 or 2; on each side of the centre line of the runway and its extended centre line throughout the length of the strip.
[Page: 433]

1.5 OBSTACLE RESTRICTION AND REMOVAL
[Page: 433]

1.5.1 OBSTACLE LIMITATION SURFACES
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.1 Outer horizontal surface Note. Guidance on the need to provide an outer horizontal surface and its characteristics is contained in the Airport Services Manual (Doc 9137), Part 6.
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.2 Conical surface
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.2.1 Description - Conical surface. A surface sloping upwards and outwards from the periphery of the inner horizontal surface.
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.2.2 Characteristics:
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.2.2.1 The limits of the conical surface shall comprise: a) a lower edge coincident with the periphery of the inner horizontal surface; and b) an upper edge located at a specified height above the inner horizontal surface.
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.2.2.2 The slope of the conical surface shall be measured in a vertical plane perpendicular to the periphery of the inner horizontal surface.
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.3 Inner horizontal surface:
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.3.1 Description - Inner horizontal surface. A surface located in a horizontal plane above an aerodrome and its environs.
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.3.2 Characteristics:
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.3.2.1 The radius or outer limits of the inner horizontal surface shall be measured from a reference point or points established for such purpose.
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.3.2.2 The height of the inner horizontal surface shall be measured above an elevation datum established for such purpose.
[Page: 433]

1.5.1.4 Approach surface
[Page: 433]

##### 1.5.1.4.1 {#id716-1.5.1.4.1}
1.5.1.4.1 Description - Approach surface: An inclined plane or combination of planes preceding the threshold. Jan 2022                   A 6                     Issue 01
[Page: 433]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 434]

1.5.1.4.2 Characteristics:
[Page: 434]

1.5.1.4.2.1 The limits of the approach surface shall comprise: a) an inner edge of specified length, horizontal and perpendicular to the extended centre line of the runway and located at a specified distance before the threshold; b) two sides originating at the ends of the inner edge and diverging uniformly at a specified rate from the extended centre line of the runway; c) an outer edge parallel to the inner edge; and d) the above surfaces shall be varied when lateral offset, offset or curved approaches are utilized, specifically, two sides originating at the ends of the inner edge and diverging uniformly at a specified rate from the extended centre line of the lateral offset, offset or curved ground track.
[Page: 434]

1.5.1.4.2.2 The elevation of the inner edge shall be equal to the elevation of the midpoint of the threshold.
[Page: 434]

1.5.1.5 Inner approach surface
[Page: 434]

1.5.1.5.1 Description - Inner approach surface. A rectangular portion of the approach surface immediately preceding the threshold.
[Page: 434]

##### 1.5.1.5.2 {#id716-1.5.1.5.2}
1.5.1.5.2 Characteristics: The limits of the inner approach surface shall comprise: a) an inner edge coincident with the location of the inner edge of the approach surface but of its own specified length; b) two sides originating at the ends of the inner edge and extending parallel to the vertical plane containing the centre line of the runway; and c) an outer edge parallel to the inner edge. Jan 2022                   A 7                     Issue 01
[Page: 434]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________ Figure 0 Appendix 1-1 Obstacle limitation surfaces
[Page: 435]

1.5.1.6 Transitional surface
[Page: 435]

1.5.1.6.1 Description - Transitional surface. A complex surface along the side of the strip and part of the side of the approach surface, that slopes upwards and outwards to the inner horizontal surface.
[Page: 435]

##### 1.5.1.6.2 {#id716-1.5.1.6.2}
1.5.1.6.2 Characteristics: Jan 2022                   A 8                     Issue 01
[Page: 435]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 436]

1.5.1.6.2.1 The limits of a transitional surface shall comprise: a) a lower edge beginning at the intersection of the side of the approach surface with the inner horizontal surface and extending down the side of the approach surface to the inner edge of the approach surface and from there along the length of the strip parallel to the runway centre line; and b) an upper edge located in the plane of the inner horizontal surface.
[Page: 436]

1.5.1.6.2.2 The elevation of a point on the lower edge shall be: a) along the side of the approach surface — equal to the elevation of the approach surface at that point; and b) along the strip — equal to the elevation of the nearest point on the centre line of the runway or its extension.
[Page: 436]

1.5.1.6.2.3 The slope of the transitional surface shall be measured in a vertical plane at right angles to the centre line of the runway.
[Page: 436]

1.5.1.7 Inner transitional surface
[Page: 436]

1.5.1.7.1 Description - Inner transitional surface. A surface similar to the transitional surface but closer to the runway.
[Page: 436]

1.5.1.7.2 Characteristics:
[Page: 436]

1.5.1.7.2.1 The limits of an inner transitional surface shall comprise: a) a lower edge beginning at the end of the inner approach surface and extending down the side of the inner approach surface to the inner edge of that surface, from there along the strip parallel to the runway centre line to the inner edge of the balked landing surface and from there up the side of the balked landing surface to the point where the side intersects the inner horizontal surface; and b) an upper edge located in the plane of the inner horizontal surface.
[Page: 436]

1.5.1.7.2.2 The elevation of a point on the lower edge shall be: a) along the side of the inner approach surface and balked landing surface — equal to the elevation of the particular surface at that point; and b) along the strip — equal to the elevation of the nearest point on the centre line of the runway or its extension.
[Page: 436]

1.5.1.7.2.3 The slope of the inner transitional surface shall be measured in a vertical plane at right angles to the centre line of the runway.
[Page: 436]

1.5.1.8 Take-off climb surface
[Page: 436]

##### 1.5.1.8.1 {#id716-1.5.1.8.1}
1.5.1.8.1 Description - Take-off climb surface. An inclined plane or other specified surface beyond the end of a runway or clearway. Jan 2022                   A 9                     Issue 01
[Page: 436]

Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS) _______________________________________________________________________________
[Page: 437]

1.5.1.8.2 Characteristics:
[Page: 437]

1.5.1.8.2.1 The limits of the take-off climb surface shall comprise: a) an inner edge horizontal and perpendicular to the centre line of the runway and located either at a specified distance beyond the end of the runway or at the end of the clearway when such is provided and its length exceeds the specified distance; b) two sides originating at the ends of the inner edge, diverging uniformly at a specified rate from the take-off track to a specified final width and continuing thereafter at that width for the remainder of the length of the take-off climb surface; and c) an outer edge horizontal and perpendicular to the specified take-off track.
[Page: 437]

1.5.1.8.2.2 The elevation of the inner edge shall be equal to the highest point on the extended runway centre line between the end of the runway and the inner edge, except that when a clearway is provided the elevation shall be equal to the highest point on the ground on the centre line of the clearway.
[Page: 437]

1.5.1.8.2.3 In the case of a straight take-off flight path, the slope of the take-off climb surface shall be measured in the vertical plane containing the centre line of the runway.
[Page: 437]

###### 1.5.1.8.2.4 {#id716-1.5.1.8.2.4}
1.5.1.8.2.4 In the case of a take-off flight path involving a turn, the take-off climb surface shall be a complex surface containing the horizontal normal to its centre line, and the slope of the centre line shall be the same as that for a straight take-off flight path. Jan 2022                   A 10                     Issue 01
[Page: 437]

FOREWORD Local Air Traffic Control Instructions (LATCI) is one of the most important, effective books for ATC units, and safe operation of flights specifically in congested aerodromes is highly related to the effective use of this document. According new format of LATCI, we decided to prepare this applicable updated LATCI by use of ICAO Annexes and documents, AIP, TEHRAN ACC &MEHRABAD APP LOC, Operational Circular issued by the ATM General Directorate of IAC, CAO.IRI rules and obligations, Air force, Sepah, and Army Local Operation Procedures (LOP) as well as Flight Information Procedures (FLIP), and other local procedures (civil & military). For the regular updates any comment and suggestion would be highly appreciated. All aeronautical experts are kindly requested to forward their views and proposals to ATS bureau of MEHRABAD airport. Changes in this document are indicated as follows: a) This vertical line (│) is inserted on reprinted pages to indicate any changes. b) An arrow is inserted on reprinted pages to indicate insertion (→) or deletion (←) in a line of text. The LATCI is complementary to MATS. Together, the two documents provide comprehensive instruction and information for ATS staff. (xv)                   01/03/2023 (V.01)
[Page: 15]

(1-1) . GENERAL
[Page: 17]

1.1 PURPOSE OF THIS ORDER The purpose of the Local Air Traffic Control Instructions is to standardize operating procedures for Air Traffic Services in MEHRABAD airspace in accordance with national and International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) Standards and Recommended Practices (SARPS). These procedures cover the airspace of MEHRABAD at or below FL275 and all IFR/VFR flights arriving at, or departing from MEHRABAD airport and flights transiting the Control Area (TMA)/ Control Zone (CTR). This order prescribes air traffic control procedures for use by persons providing air traffic control services. Controllers are required to be familiar with the provisions of this order that pertain to their operational responsibilities and to exercise their best judgment if they encounter situations that are not covered by it.
[Page: 17]

1.2 AUDIENCE This order applies to all ATC personnel and anyone using ATC directives within MEHRABAD airport and its airspaces.
[Page: 17]

1.3 WHERE TO FIND THIS ORDER This order is available at ATC bureau of MEHRABAD airport and Inspection and Uniformity Bureau of general directorate of ATC in Tehran.
[Page: 17]

1.5 EXPLANATION OF CHANGES The significant changes to this order are identified in the Explanation of Changes page(s). It is advisable to retain the page(s) throughout the duration of the basic order.
[Page: 18]

1.6 RECOMMENDATIONS FOR PROCEDURAL CHANGES Any recommended changes to this order must be submitted to the Inspection and Uniformity Bureau in Tehran. Personnel should submit recommended changes in procedures to aerodrome ATS bureau.
[Page: 18]

1.7 PROCEDURAL LETTERS OF AGREEMENT MILITARY PROCEDURES Procedures/minima which are applied for the military operations require the approval of the local military headquarters and must be documented in a letter of agreement. The military letters of agreement shall be attached at the end of the military section of this manual. Letters of agreement is necessary to supplement the related parts of this order.
[Page: 18]

1.8 CONSTRAINTS GOVERNING SUPPLEMENTS AND PROCEDURAL DEVIATIONS a) Exceptional or unusual requirements may dictate procedural deviations or supplementary procedures to this order. Prior to implementing supplemental or any procedural deviation that alters the level, quality, or degree of service; obtain prior approval from the General directorate of ATC. b) If military operations or facilities are involved, an official prior approval from the appropriate local military headquarters is required.
[Page: 18]

1.9 REFERENCES TO NON-AIR TRAFFIC ORGANIZATIONS When references are made to organizations that are not part of the Air Traffic Organization (i.e. Communications Center, Flight Standards, Airport offices, etc.), that references shall be indicated in an appropriate way to the sake of responsibility.
[Page: 18]

(3-1) . UNIT   ORGANIZATION
[Page: 31]

3.1 HOURS OF OPERATION The ATC Unit operates H24 and currently runs 5 shifts. Roster, 5-day shift cycle are available – 12 hr. work, 48 hr. rest based on the following: Table 3-1 Shift rotation Shift           Start                  End First           06:30                  18:00 Second           18:00                  06:30 Note: The monthly watch-keeping schedule will normally be prepared before 28th of each Shamsi month by the head of MEHRABAD ATC and approved by airport deputy of aviation operation.
[Page: 31]

3.2 ATC UNITS MEHRABAD ATS has three separate units. These units are: approach, aerodrome, and ground control.
[Page: 31]

### 3.2.1 {#id717-3.2.1}
3.2.1 APPROACH CONTROL Approach control is responsible for all arriving aircraft released to it by ACC and departure aircraft after they are handed over by the TWR until they can be transferred to ACC. Approach control is also responsible to provide air traffic services to all IFR/VFR traffic entering, leaving, transiting or operating within TRN TMA and MEHRABAD CTR. (OIII LATCI)                                          01/03/2023 (V.01)
[Page: 31]

3-2                                            Mehrabad Int. Airport LATCI
[Page: 32]

3.2.2 AERODROME CONTROL Aerodrome Control is responsible for providing air traffic services to all aircraft operating within the MEHRABAD ATZ (5NM) radius centered on the ARP at or below 5500 feet and all arriving aircraft released to it by APP and to all departing aircraft before being released to APP.
[Page: 32]

3.2.3 GROUND CONTROL Ground Control is responsible for providing air traffic services to all aerodrome traffic on the movement area except runways and taxi-lanes. Any vehicle or person operating in this area is required to request clearance from Ground Control. This is done via VHF radio on 121.9, but there may be special cases where other processes are used such as radio trunk. Vehicles, people working on the Maneuvering Area must have a communications link through which they can communicate with Ground Control, commonly by handheld radio.
[Page: 32]

(6-1) . STAFF    RESPONSIBILITIES
[Page: 43]

6.1 DIVISIONS OF RESPONSIBILITIES There are no absolute divisions of responsibilities regarding position operations. The tasks to be completed remain the same whether one, two, or three people are working positions. The team as a whole has responsibility for the safe and efficient operations of ATS members.
[Page: 43]

6.2 TEAM RESPONSIBILITIES The intent of the team concept is not to hold the team accountable for the action of individual members in the event of an operational error/deviation.
[Page: 43]

## 6.3 {#id717-6.3}
6.3 OPERATIONAL RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE ATC SUPERVISOR ATC supervisor works under the authority of ATS chief and he/she shall have valid OIII APP/ RADAR rating. The ATC supervisor is responsible for: a) Ensuring that operating positions are occupied by qualified personnel who are in current operating practice and ensure that staff are kept operationally proficient; Note. All control positions should be provided with assistant. b) Maintaining the ATS watch log and ensuring that all relevant details are recorded; Note: For complementary info on ATS Watch Log, refer to appendix 5. c) Supervising the process of controlling air traffic in different stages of flight within TMA/CTR. d) Supervising the air traffic control unit under the responsibility and ensure the implementation of regulation. e) Monitoring the personnel on duty and adjusting the functions of operating positions so as to meet the traffic demand in an adequate manner; (OIII LATCI)                                          01/03/2023 (V.01)
[Page: 43]

6-2                                            Mehrabad Int. Airport LATCI f) Carrying out frequent checks on CNS/ATM facilities and draw the attention of personnel concerned to any errors, omissions, irregularities or the use of non-standard procedures; g) Filling the relevant forms (such as E101, E102, …) h) Recommending to ATS chief, improvements to procedures and operating methods; i) Working as duty controller often enough to maintain validity of his/her ratings; j) Handing/Taking over the ATC operational team. k) Reporting to the ATS chief: 10. Changes in serviceability of navigational and ATC equipment and facilities; 11. Non-compliance with regulations and procedures; 12. Complaints or incidents involving the ATC service; 13. Any other matters of general operational interest;
[Page: 44]

## 6.4 {#id717-6.4}
6.4 TWR SUPERVISOR Note: TWR Supervisor may be selected, by coordination with ATC Chief, from competent TWR controllers. TWR supervisor should have valid OIII APP/RADAR rating and is responsible for: a) Supervising the correct implementation of planned team program. b) Supervising the discipline of the people in the TWR. c) Monitoring the performance of the positions in the TWR and providing useful information to them especially in case of bad weather, emergency situations, special flights such as VIP, SAR, FLTCK, congested traffic and etc. d) Monitoring the proper operation of the equipment and all instruments in the TWR. e) Reporting to the ATC supervisor any fault developing in the equipment’s, irregularity in the planned program prepared by ATC supervisor, any incident in accordance with incident reporting procedure (Refer to Safety Management Manual SM10) or any instances affecting ATS service. f) Checking that the latest NOTAMs to be applied by personnel. g) Managing the probable conflicts between ATC units or between traffic and ATC units. Note: in case of interfering the TWR/GND duties, all such interferences should be affected via recording equipment (e.g., intercoms, microphones, etc.). h) Keeping efficient coordination with ATC supervisor. Note. The presence of TWR supervisor does not relieve the controllers of their responsibilities and he/she is not responsible for the deliberate or inadvertent errors committed by the controllers. i) Performing other duties relative to ATC operations as may be assigned to her/him by the ATC supervisor. 01/03/2023 (V.01)

6.5 APPROACH CONTROLLER AND ASSISTANT
[Page: 45]

6.5.1 GENERAL Approach controller is responsible for control of all arriving aircraft, according LOC, released to it by ACC and airborne aircraft after they are handed over by the TWR until they, according LOC, can be transferred to ACC. Approach controller is also responsible to handle all traffic [e.g. transiting or operating within TMA, within controlled/defined/specific airspace - including limitations]. Note: All on-duty controllers work under the authority of ATC supervisor.
[Page: 45]

### 6.5.2 {#id717-6.5.2}
6.5.2 APPROACH CONTROLLER Approach controller shall have valid OIII APP/ RADAR rating. The approach controller is responsible for: a) Following hand over/take over checklist before signing on/off the related form. (refer to attachment B) b) Providing air traffic services to aircraft within defined AOR as follows: 1. Local flights operating within the CTR and/or TMA, 2. Overflying aircraft under the control of APP RADAR/APP at or below FL275, 3. Arriving aircraft from the time they are transferred by ACC until being transferred to TWR, 4. Departing aircraft from the time of departure until being transferred to ACC. c) Providing Radar control service within TRN TMA in accordance with AIP ENR1.6 and DOC 4444 part 8. d) Having efficient coordination with other relevant units according to published LOC. e) Reporting to the ATC supervisor any fault developing in the equipment, any incident requiring investigation or any instances affecting ATS service. f) Coordinating with TWR before accepting the aircraft to use a runway other than the runway in use. (Ref to AIP OIII AD2.22 item 9) g) Release of inbound traffic from APP to OIII TWR 1. When executing visual approach: In the vicinity of aerodrome, below 7000ft and reported the runway is in sight; or 2. At one of the following points provided that the reported visibility is at or above absolute operation minima and: i. Establishing LLZ (when executing ILS approach); or ii. On the final approach track (when executing a non-precision approach); or iii. On the "GATE" for fighter aircraft (when executing TACAN or SHORAN approach); or 01/03/2023 (V.01)
[Page: 45]

6-4                                            Mehrabad Int. Airport LATCI iv. At 2 minutes to initial for fighter aircraft (when executing initial/break landing); or Note1: when the reported visibility is below aerodrome absolute minima, the aircraft should remain on the APP frequency until the landing has been completed. In this case RADAR/APP should obtain landing clearance from aerodrome control and pass it to the aircraft. Note2: In any situations that the arriving aircraft should remain on APP frequency until it comes to a full stop, any crossing or entering RWYs or take-off clearance should be coordinated with APP unit. h) Release of inbound traffic from APP to OIIE TWR According coordination procedure. Refer to Appendix 6. i) Release of inbound traffic from APP to OIIP TWR According coordination procedure. Refer to Appendix 6. j) Performing other duties relative to ATC operations as may be assigned to her/him by the ATC supervisor k) Coordinating with TWR before accepting visual approach. l) Monitoring the flight progress to ensure that the flights (for radar service): 1. Remain within 5NM of the assigned route's center line; 2. Are clear from confined areas; 3. Make correct turns and follow specified tracks after departure; 4. Are within holding patterns Note: Ensure minimum radar separation is applied and will be maintained between successive arrivals before changing to TWR. 6.9 SWAPPING OF SHIFT/LEAVING DUTY
[Page: 53]

6.9.1 Controllers are not allowed to swap shift without the approval from ATS office/Supervisor and an agreement must be written and signed in the ATC attendance log book at least a day prior to the effective date.
[Page: 53]

6.9.2 Additionally, controllers are not allowed to leave the control position without being properly relieved. However, any controller desiring to leave duty before his/her quitting hour must inform the ATC Supervisor and arrange to have a colleague to sit in before leaving. Note. Swapping shift could be done maximum two times per month. The third one may be acceptable only by prior coordination with ATS office.
[Page: 53]

6.10 HANDING-OVER / TAKING-OVERAN OPERATIONAL POSITION
[Page: 53]

6.10.1 GENERAL When a prevailing traffic situation or other event makes it desirable for a controller to complete all actions before transferring responsibility to another controller, he should remain on duty until such time as these actions have been completed. Prior to handing over watch or an operating position, the controllers must: a) ensure that she/he provide their successors with the fullest possible information regarding the current traffic situation, including any items of specific interest or urgency, b) Sign the Air Traffic Control Position Log as having handed over watch When the Controller taking over is fully conversant with the air traffic situation and is prepared to assume full responsibility for the watch. Refer to appendix 7.
[Page: 53]

### 6.10.2 {#id717-6.10.2}
6.10.2 HAND-OVER The responsibility for the accuracy of the hand over lies with the person vacating an operational position. This does not remove all responsibility from the Controller taking over who must be aware that the Controller being relieved may well be exhausted. The order in which information should be passed from one controller to another should be as follows: a) General information, including any variations from routine operations; b) Other supplementary information relating to the position; c) The detailed traffic situation. The Controller taking over must be alerted to the possibility of errors and omissions in the information given. She/he must verify the data transferred by a thorough check of the flight progress strips and any other relevant information. She/he must also clearly indicate to the Controller handing over when he is ready to accept responsibility for the operational position/watch. Prior to handing over watch or an operating position, the controllers must: 01/03/2023 (V.01)

The time required for handover will depend on the complexity of the situation which should not less than 5 minutes. When a controller is assigned to an operating position, he should normally not handover responsibility for the performance of the duties associated with this position to any other controller unless he is authorized to do so by the supervisor on duty. Before vacating an operating position for any reason while a unit is still in operation, the controller vacating that position should ensure that there is a clear understanding as to who will assume responsibility for that particular operating position and an appropriate handover should be affected. It is essential that all controllers occupying an operating position are in a satisfactory state of health throughout their period of duty. Accordingly, a controller should not assume or retain responsibility for any ATS operating position if his capacity to perform the duties of the position is in any way impaired because of sickness, injury, fatigue, personal worry or his emotional state. A controller who considers that his physical or emotional state is such that his ability to perform his duties satisfactorily may be impaired should notify the supervisor on duty, and that supervisor should make necessary release arrangements.

8.10 APPLICATION OF WAKE TURBULENCE SEPARATION Note 1. Runways 29L (11R) and 29R (11L) should be considered as one runway regarding wake turbulence. Note 2. Any fighters should not depart or land closer than 4 minutes behind HEAVY aircraft. Note 3. Aircraft holding on taxiways between runways should maintain engines at low RPM while other aircraft are taking off or landing behind. Note 4. Fighters are Medium as a preceding aircraft, but as a succeeding aircraft should be considered as Light. Note 5. When an aircraft requests clearance for a touch-and-go, the aircraft must be considered as making a departure from an intersection for vortex wake purposes. Note6: Refer to MATS, 3.1.11. ## 9.2 {#id717-9.2}
9.2 INTRODUCTIONS This procedure is for providing surveillance radar to assist in the provision of air traffic services. ATS surveillance system at OIII consists of primary/secondary surveillance radar. ATS surveillance service within Mehrabad AOR (Area of Responsibility) will be available only when SSR system operates normal. Ref AIP ENR 1.6, Since OIII ATS surveillance system is not capable of detecting and displaying areas of adverse weather, pilots are responsible for circumnavigating in adverse weather. The radar controller will monitor the flight progress to ensure that the flights: a) Remain within 5 NM of the assigned route's center line; b) Are clear from confined areas; c) Make correct turns and follow specified tracks; d) Are within holding patterns. Flight path monitoring of air traffic is provided, except for final approach, since the ATS surveillance system being used is not qualified for provision of ATS in that segment. Departure instructions may contain some restrictions for the purpose of providing non-Radar separation until establishment of identification and the provision of radar control. (OIII LATCI)                                          01/03/2023 (V.01)

Airport LATCI In no circumstances succeeding departure aircraft shall be released except when preceding aircraft has been identified and the reasonable assurance exist that radar or non-radar separation can be provided by MEHRABAD radar controller. When radar service is not provided by Tehran ACC, non-radar separation shall be applied between departure aircraft before releasing them to the Tehran ACC. The radar controller should ensure that the aerodrome controller is kept informed of the sequence of arriving aircraft, as well as any instructions and restrictions which have been issued to such aircraft in order to maintain separation after transfer of control to the aerodrome controller.

10.3 ALTIMETER SETTING PROCEDURES (INCLUDING QFE CORRECTION) Current altimeter settings must be obtained from weather reporting stations. (OIII LATCI)                                          01/03/2023 (V.01)
[Page: 75]

10-2                                           Mehrabad Int. Airport LATCI In flight, when an aircraft is at or below the transition altitude, its vertical position is expressed in terms of altitude, which is determined from an altimeter set to sea level pressure (QNH). The reported QNH is valid within 25 NM. In flight above the transition altitude, the vertical position of an aircraft is expressed in terms of flight levels, which are surfaces of constant atmospheric pressure based on an altimeter setting of 1013.2 hPa (29.92 inches). The following correction factors must be applied to the QFE value supplies by the MET office: a) 4hpa deducted from the QFE value for threshold of runway 29; b) 2hpa added to QFE value for threshold of runway 11.

11.1.1 PROCEDURES FOR CHECKING THE CRASH ALARM AND ALERTING FIRE FIGHTING SERVICE The civil crash alarm should be checked at the beginning of each watch of firefighting station (with time and frequency check) or after maintenance work, three times for two seconds each with an interval of one second. The military crash alarm should be checked three times for two seconds each with an interval of one second; with prior coordination with representative of IRAF at 08:00 (LCL) every morning as prescribed by base operation. The status of alerting alarm(s) shall be reported to tower controller by Command Post (CP). Note 1: Any unserviceability of the civil crash alarm should be reported to ATC supervisor. Note 2: When crash alarm is U/S, to exchange safety related information, the available voice communication facilities and/or telephone lines (direct or extension) should be used.
[Page: 78]

11.1.2 METHOD OF ALERTING FIRE-FIGHTING STATIONS In addition to crash alarm, alerting firefighting stations should be done by one of the following means in order: a) radio frequency (on 121.9 MHz) b) intercom c) internal telephone (3333; 3085) d) radio trunk (636)
[Page: 78]

11.1.3 PROCEDURES FOR ALERTING FIRE- FIGHTING PERSONNEL To alert rescue and firefighting service in emergency situation, the alarm bell should be actuated twice with 5 seconds duration and with two seconds interval. In case of full emergency, the alarm bell should be actuated once for 10 seconds duration. 11.3 AIRCRAFT INCIDENTS AND ACCIDENTS
[Page: 79]

### 11.3.1 {#id717-11.3.1}
11.3.1 AIRCRAFT ACCIDENT Tower controller action In the event of an aircraft accident, following actions should be taken by tower controller and/or tower assistant controller: Note. The same action should be taken by ground controller and/or ground assistant, when an accident happens to an aircraft under the jurisdiction of ground controller or near the airport and out of sight tower controller and tower assistant. a) Press the crash alarm according to the related procedures. b) Advise the airport fire service of the location of the accident by radio frequency (on 121.9 MHz), intercom, internal telephone (3333; 3085) or radio trunk (636) about: 1. Location of accident; 2. Type of accident; 3. Type of aircraft; 4. Wind direction and velocity; 5. Other necessary information if available; fuel endurance, POB, etc. c) Advise IRIAF fire service by available means, When the aircraft is military or if controller find it necessary; d) Advise ATC Supervisor, and e) Listen out on 121.9 MHz ATC Supervisor action Note: It is obvious that during an emergency situation, the ATC Supervisor is involved in managing the emergency situation, so the notification process may take some time. ATC Supervisor, after receiving information of aircraft accident should, as soon as practicable, inform the authorities listed below giving the type of accident; type and location of aircraft; aircraft identification and total number of persons on board: a) MEHRABAD ATS chief or his deputy, b) Airport deputy of aviation operation, c) Airport security, d) Flight standards staff in duty Written report a) All actions taken should be filed in the ATS watch log as soon as possible. 01/03/2023 (V.01)
[Page: 79]

11-4                                           Mehrabad Int. Airport LATCI b) All controllers involved should submit a written report on the accident to the ATS watch supervisor before leaving the airport. c) The ATC Supervisor should ensure that any necessary reporting action has been taken. d) Requests for information from the press or other outside persons should be refused. Such requests should be referred to CAA.IRI & IAC public relations. e) An accident will be declared closed only after receiving information from the fire station.
[Page: 80]

11.3.2 AIRCRAFT INCIDENT The controller or his/her assistance shall, as soon as practicable, inform ATC supervisor of any known incident.
[Page: 80]

11.4 UNCERTAINTY PHASE (LOCAL STANDBY) Uncertainty phase starts when an aircraft is known or suspected to have an operational defect that should not normally cause serious difficulty in achieving a safe landing (i.e. test flight, bad weather, etc.). This is a notification only and no response is required. All units involved will be manned and will standby in stations.
[Page: 80]

### 11.4.1 {#id717-11.4.1}
11.4.1 ACTION TO BE TAKEN BY ATC Tower controller should advise the related firefighting services “STANDBY” in following situations: a) FCF (functional check flight); b) Fast Taxi c) MNM Fuel; d) Bad weather, such as TS; e) Gun-stoppage, unless pilot declares an emergency; f) Any training fighter flight that the pilot report executing no flap, single engine and other unusual operations; g) When cross wind component is 20 KT or more; h) When LVP is in progress; i) Slippery runway surface according to GRF, RCC (Runway Condition Code); j) When controller finds it necessary. Tower controller and/or tower assistant controller should pass the following details to firefighting station, as required: a) Situation occurred; b) Type of aircraft; c) Nature of trouble; 01/03/2023 (V.01)
[Page: 80]

Chapter11. Emergency, In-Flight Contingency And Related Coordination 11-5 d) ETA; and e) Wind direction and velocity and runway-in-use. Tower controller and/or tower assistant controller shall advise ATC Supervisor of such action taken. Firefighting station shall be informed when “STANDBY” situation is terminated.
[Page: 81]

11.5 ALERT PHASE (FULL EMERGENCY) Alert phase is initiated when an aircraft is known or suspected to have an operational defect that affects normal flight operations to the extent that there is danger of an accident. All related units should be informed with the following information: a) Aircraft identification; b) Nature of emergency; c) Position of aircraft; d) Total number of person on board and; and e) Fuel on board.
[Page: 81]

### 11.5.1 {#id717-11.5.1}
11.5.1 ACTION TO BE TAKEN BY ATC After receiving information of emergency aircraft, the related controller should activate the civil and military crash alarm and pass the following details: a) Type of aircraft; b) Nature of emergency; c) Estimated time of landing; d) Total number of persons on board (if practicable); e) Remaining fuel; f) Wind direction and velocity and runway in use; and g) Name of operating company. The related controller should advise ATC Supervisor of an emergency as soon as possible. The ATC Supervisor should inform these authorities: a) MEHRABAD ATS chief or his deputy, b) Airport deputy of aviation operation, c) Airport security, 01/03/2023 (V.01)
[Page: 81]

11-6                                           Mehrabad Int. Airport LATCI d) Flight standards office. Note 1: The ATC SUP should fill out the related form (E101). Note 2: According to traffic condition, informing may be passed with delay. An emergency shall be declared closed when information has been received by the pilot of the related aircraft that the emergency situation is terminated.
[Page: 82]
